content.webTitle: Ryan Hampshire’s late penalty salvages draw for Wakefield at Leeds

fields.headline: Ryan Hampshire’s late penalty salvages draw for Wakefield at Leeds
fields.bodyText: Leeds Rhinos must now win both their remaining Super League games to stand any chance of avoiding a battle against relegation in the Qualifiers this summer after yet again surrendering a winning position to drop points, this time against Wakefield. Kevin Sinfield’s 19-year playing career with the Rhinos featured many memorable moments at Headingley but his first outing as a coach here will arguably rank as one of his more frustrating evenings. Leeds’ record eight-match losing run appeared destined to end when the Rhinos led by eight points with nine minutes remaining: but old habits, it seem, die hard. Kyle Wood’s try, followed by two goals from the boot of Ryan Hampshire, ensured there would be no winning return to Headingley for Sinfield – with this the third time in less than a month Leeds have collapsed from a winning position to drop a point. At least they arrested their losing run, which gave Sinfield something to hold on to. “We’re not quite ready to win yet,” he said. “But after that showing, we’re on track and can fix things up.” Wakefield would have arguably been favourites to finish ninth had they lost here - but this dramatic fightback alleviates the pressure on them without doubt. “I’m very happy with the point,” their coach, Chris Chester said. “That’s what we’re all about.” In a game with the stakes so high it was perhaps no surprise neither side produced their best all evening – but the greater moments of promise in the first half came from the hosts. They led 18-12 thanks to tries for Ryan Hall, Ash Handley and Richie Myler: and, given their dominance, they should have been further ahead. As it was, Wakefield made them pay. All Leeds could muster after half-time was a penalty from the boot of Liam Sutcliffe and, while this was undoubtedly an improved effort from Leeds, Wakefield produced a compelling fightback to deny them victory. First, Wood claimed his own kick which Hampshire converted - before the scrum-half added a late penalty of his own in the final moments to secure a point. Leeds Walker; Briscoe, Sutcliffe, Handley, Hall; Moon, Myler; Garbutt, Dwyer, Singleton, Ablett, Ferres, Cuthbertson. Interchange Walters, Ward, Oledzki, Golding. Tries Hall, Myler, Handley Goals Sutcliffe 4. Wakefield Jowitt; Jones-Bishop, Lyne, Tupou, Johnstone; Miller, Hampshire; Fifita, Randell, England, Ashurst, Horo, Annakin. Interchange Wood, Pauli, Arona, Hirst. Tries Tupou, Horo, Wood Goals Hampshire 4. Referee R Hicks. Attendance 11,140.
